item.title: Best Movies of 2025
item.description: Our film critics rank their 10 favorites of the year.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Put Your Soul on Your Hand and Walk (Movie)

item.title: Doctor Who Gave Matthew Perry Ketamine Is Sentenced to 30 Months
item.description: The doctor, Salvador Plasencia, had asked “I wonder how much this moron will pay” before supplying the drug to Mr. Perry, who became increasingly reliant on it before his death.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Damian Dovarganes/Associated Press
item.media:description: “I’m just so sorry,” Salvador Plasencia told Matthew Perry’s family during the sentencing hearing on Wednesday.

item.title: Steve Cropper, Guitarist, Songwriter and Shaper of Memphis Soul Music, Dies at 84
item.description: As a member of Booker T. & the MG’s and as a producer, he played a pivotal role in the rise of Stax Records, a storied force in R&B in the 1960s and ’70s.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: (Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay (Song)
item.media:credit: David Reed Archive/Alamy
item.media:description: Steve Cropper in 1973. His guitar licks could be heard in hits by Otis Redding, Sam & Dave and Wilson Pickett, among many others.

item.title: Which Films Could Be Nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars?
item.description: “One Battle After Another,” “Sinners,” “Hamnet,” “Marty Supreme” and “Sentimental Value” are almost certain to be nominated. After that, it’s anyone’s guess.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: ‘Oh. What. Fun.,’ ‘My Secret Santa’ and More Christmas Movies to Stream
item.description: From “Oh. What. Fun.” to “A Very Jonas Christmas Movie,” a roundup of several new holiday titles to stream this season.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Alisha Wetherill/Prime
item.media:description: Michelle Pfeiffer in “Oh. What. Fun.”

item.title: Sondheim’s ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ Is Now a Film. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The Broadway revival, starring Daniel Radcliffe, Jonathan Groff and Lindsay Mendez, was transformative. Here’s what to know about the show, and the movie.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonathan Groff, with Daniel Radcliffe and other cast members, at the “Merrily We Roll Along” taping in 2024.

item.title: Mormon Women Are Taking Over Our Screens
item.description: Across reality shows, social media and best-selling books, women raised in the church have increased its profile across pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City (TV Program)
The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives (TV Program)

item.title: Paul Williams, Songwriter for the Muppets and the Carpenters, Takes a Bow
item.description: Paul Williams is known for his ability to elicit both laughter and tears. This week, he and his decades of music will be celebrated at the 92nd Street Y.
item.dc:creator: Elysa Gardner
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: “I never had a treehouse when I was a kid, a place where you’d be up hanging with your gang,” Williams said. “As soon as I walked on the set and met the Muppets and Jim, I had a treehouse.”

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love the A.A.C.M.
item.description: The Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians in Chicago has built community and pushed musical boundaries for 60 years. Hear 13 tracks from this jazz institution.
item.dc:creator: Marcus J. Moore
item.category: Assn for the Advancement of Creative Musicians

item.title: American Sports Are Turning Up the Volume of Afrobeats
item.description: With an eye on its international fan base, the N.B.A. has welcomed the influence of African singers like Tems, Burna Boy and Rema.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett/Getty Images
item.media:description: Burna Boy performing at halftime of the N.B.A. All-Star Game in 2023. This year his hit single “Don’t Let Me Drown” was featured on the soundtrack of “F1: The Movie.”

item.title: ‘Vanderpump Rules’ Is Back With a New Cast. Here Are 4 Takeaways.
item.description: The Season 12 premiere got back to the show’s roots, introducing a young cast with the kind of hunger and fresh faces that made the original a hit.
item.dc:creator: Ali Trachta

item.title: Holiday Theater: 15 Shows to Spice Up Your Festive Season
item.description: Enticements abound in New York City, including Jinkx Monsoon crooning, Dickens reciting Dickens and, for the whole family, the Big Apple Circus.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: It's a Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play (Play)

item.title: Inside the Museum-Style Home of Michael Ovitz, an A-List Collector
item.description: He is best known as a former Hollywood power broker, but Ovitz has filled his Beverly Hills home with a collection that shows how serious he is about art.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Ovitz and Tamara Mellon in front of “The Seven Deadly Sins,” by Cecily Brown.

item.title: They Used Art as ‘Fake News’ to Sell Colonialism. This Show Is a Fact Check.
item.description: A new exhibition at the Africa Museum in Belgium takes a frank look at a large-scale propaganda painting and the institution’s own past role in adding to the spin.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.category: Belgian Royal Museum for Central Africa
item.media:credit: Lusófona University/Luca School of Arts
item.media:description: A detail of “The Congo Panorama” by Alfred Bastien and Paul Mathieu, in which the artists transformed the harsh reality of colonial life into utopian fantasy.

item.title: Spotify Wrapped Has Users Talking About Their ‘Listening Age’
item.description: The wrinkle in this year’s Spotify Wrapped release was an estimate of the user’s “listening age.” Some wore it like a badge of honor. Others made excuses.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher

item.title: Mel Leipzig, Painter Called the ‘Chekhov of Trenton,’ Dies at 90
item.description: He put fellow New Jerseyans at the center of his work, and a critic praised the “mysterious emotional tensions” in his pictures of ordinary people.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: ‘Bel-Air,’ the ‘Fresh Prince’ Reboot, Ends Its Unlikely Run
item.description: With the “Fresh Prince” reboot ending next week, Morgan Stevenson Cooper looks back on its path from viral video to Peacock hit.
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito and Erik Carter
item.category: The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Erik Carter for The New York Times

item.title: Late Night Reviews Trump’s ‘Social Media Blitzkrieg’
item.description: The president posted 160 times on Truth Social in one night, according to news reports. One host says his “thumbs were as swollen as his ankles.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: David Pryce-Jones, Conservative Writer With Clout, Dies at 89
item.description: The author of novels, histories, biographies and influential political essays, he approached them all with a droll British wit and a steadfast commitment to Western values.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Dijon, a Studio Maestro, Is Stepping Into the Spotlight
item.description: Onstage in Brooklyn, the buzzy producer and musician blasted his songs apart and stitched them back together again.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dijon played songs from his latest album, “Baby!,” at the Brooklyn Paramount on Monday night.

item.title: 11 Musical Love Letters From Artists to Their Heroes
item.description: Hear the Replacements (on Big Star), Sonic Youth (on Karen Carpenter), Stevie Wonder (on Duke Ellington) and more.
item.media:credit: Paul Natkin/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Replacements

item.title: Finding the Magic, Just in Time (Encore)
item.description: Clare Cory was 59 years old and had been single almost her whole life. She thought her love story was over. Then everything changed.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Christina Djossa, Amy Pearl, Sara Curtis, Elisa Gutierrez, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez and Dan Powell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times, Inset Illustration by Brian Rea

item.title: See All the Stars at the Gotham Awards: Elle Fanning, Hugh Jackman and More
item.description: It was all roast beef, chocolate cake and air kisses at the Gotham Awards in Lower Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Rebecca Smeyne
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times

item.title: A Skating Rink Was Built Around a Luciano Pavarotti Statue. People Aren’t Thrilled.
item.description: “Nessun Dorma?” More like “Ice, Ice Baby,” as a statue in Italy is overshadowed.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Luca Toni/il Resto del Carlino
item.media:description: Luciano Pavarotti and a skating rink in Pesaro, Italy. What could go wrong?

item.title: The Choreographer Tere O’Connor Adds ‘Explainer’ to His Repertoire
item.description: After 40 years of making dances as complicated as human consciousness, Tere O’Connor revives his first work at New York Live Arts. Bonus: He will talk about it.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Tess Mayer for The New York Times

item.title: Why Are There So Many Films Right Now Based on the Bible?
item.description: Films that take their stories from the Old or New Testament are filling screens big and small. To understand why, it helps to know Hollywood history.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.media:credit: Magnolia Pictures, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nicolas Cage as Joseph in “The Carpenter’s Son,” one of a host of recent and forthcoming movies based on biblical stories.

item.title: Take a Look at T Magazine’s Gen X Covers by David Silverman of “The Simpsons” and Chris Ware
item.description: On two of T Magazine’s Holiday Issue covers, an era’s biggest stars appear as Simpsons characters. A third features Chris Ware’s illustrations of the goods of his youth.

item.title: Whatever: A Gen X Glossary
item.description: “Androgyny,” “apathy” and other words and ideas that defined America’s last monoculture.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs

item.title: For Royal Danish Ballet, It’s Back to Bournonville
item.description: After years focused on international repertory and new work, the company is returning the choreographer August Bournonville, “our place of belonging,” to the heart of its mission.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss
item.media:credit: Mathias Eis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Danish Royal Ballet Stephanie Chen Gundorph, left, and Joseph Aumeer in Copenhagen rehearse under a bust of Bournonville.

item.title: The 10 Best Books of 2025
item.description: After a year of deliberation, the editors at The New York Times Book Review have picked their 10 best books of 2025. Three editors share their favorites.
item.dc:creator: MJ Franklin, Joumana Khatib, Elisabeth Egan, Claire Hogan, Laura Salaberry, Gabriel Blanco and Karen Hanley

item.title: What Is Gen X’s Legacy?
item.description: The generation known for its irony also taught us something about engaging earnestly with art.
item.dc:creator: Hanya Yanagihara

item.title: Can a Celebrity Be Conservative in Trump’s America?
item.description: A conversation with the columnist Ross Douthat about how popular culture is reacting to a second Trump administration.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Graham Dickie for The New York Times (YoungBoy Never Broke Again); Gareth Cattermole/Getty Images for BFI (Sydney Sweeney)

item.title: Is Gen X Actually the Greatest Generation?
item.description: How one era changed everything about the culture — and why we’re so nostalgic for its creations.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Fortini and Neal Slavin

item.title: Es Devlin Builds a ‘Library of Us’ From the Books That Shaped Her
item.description: For Miami Art Week, Devlin has created an open-air installation for Faena Art that invites the public to turn her personal library into a communal one.
item.dc:creator: Nazanin Lankarani
item.media:credit: Daniel Terna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Es Devlin sorted through thousands of books for her installation “Library of Us” at the Kadan Productions warehouse in Secaucus, N.J., in October, marking the titles she wanted displayed spine out with yellow tape.

item.title: The Pérez Art Museum Miami Wants to Be the ‘People’s Museum’
item.description: Franklin Sirmans, head of the Pérez Art Museum Miami, discusses building its collection, the dearth of Black art museum directors and navigating Florida politics.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos
item.category: Perez, Jorge M, Art Museum of Miami-Dade County
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I do believe that we have proved to be the people’s museum in Miami, in a place that has been much more well known for its private collections,” Sirmans said of PAMM.

item.title: Late Night Lashes Out at Trump’s Tim Walz Taunt
item.description: “On Thanksgiving? Are you confusing that with Festivus?” Jon Stewart said of President Trump’s Truth Social post insulting the Minnesota governor’s intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Jafar Panahi, Who Filmed in Secret in Iran, Wins Big at Gotham Awards
item.description: He won best director, original screenplay and international feature for “It Was Just an Accident.” Best feature went to “One Battle After Another.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jafar Panahi at the Gothams on Monday.

item.title: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader Join Forces to Form New Art Gallery
item.description: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader of Sotheby’s are collaborating on an Upper East Side space that will focus on secondary market sales.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: via Pace Gallery, Photo by Thomas Loof; George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of Pace Gallery, New York (left), and the Di Donna Gallery (right). They will merge into a new location on the Upper East Side, and David Schrader will join the leaders of those galleries in a new venture.

item.title: ‘The Merchants of Joy’ Review: Cutthroat Christmas Tree Sales
item.description: A new documentary contains zesty character studies of competing New York City tree vendors as they prepare for the holiday season.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: Best Movies and Shows Streaming in December 2025
item.description: “F1: The Movie,” “It’s Never Over, Jeff Buckley” and “The Life of Chuck” arrive, and “Fallout” and “Percy Jackson” return.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.category: Percy Jackson and the Olympians (TV Program)

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in December
item.description: A slew of new titles are coming this month, including the latest “Knives Out” mystery and a film starring George Clooney and Adam Sandler.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: Nathan Lane and Laurie Metcalf to Star in ‘Death of a Salesman’ on Broadway
item.description: Joe Mantello will direct the next revival of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman,” opening in April at the Winter Garden Theater.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: CJ Rivera/Invision, via Associated Press, Rob Grabowski/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nathan Lane, who was last on Broadway in 2023, and Laurie Metcalf, who is currently in the Broadway production of “Little Bear Ridge Road,” will star opposite each other as Willy and Linda Loman.

item.title: 13 Plays to See in December Featuring Michelle Williams, Matthew Broderick and More Stars
item.description: Michelle Williams leads an O’Neill drama, Matthew Broderick stars in Molière, and plenty of stages brim with non-holiday fare, Off Broadway and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions (Opera)
item.media:credit: Richard Shotwell/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Michelle Williams is starring in “Anna Christie” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.

item.title: Two Galleries Form New Art Prize
item.description: The FLAG Art Foundation in New York and Serpentine in London have established a 1 million British pound award for five artists.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Serpentine x FLAG Art Foundation Prize
item.media:credit: via Serpentine
item.media:description: From left: Patti Harris; Hans Ulrich Obrist; Amanda Fuhrman; Glenn Fuhrman, the founder of the FLAG Art Foundation; Bettina Korek, chief executive of Serpentine; and Michael Bloomberg.

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs Demands Netflix Drop 50 Cent Series, Citing New Footage
item.description: The mogul’s lawyers told the streaming service to withdraw a documentary because it was produced by his rival and uses footage they say was “illicitly” acquired.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sean Combs is the subject of a new documentary series executive produced by his longtime rival, 50 Cent, that includes footage Mr. Combs commissioned in the days leading up to his 2024 arrest.

item.title: On the Eve of Art Basel Miami Beach, a Case of the Jitters
item.description: Fourteen galleries pulled out of the fair this year, while others chose to stay and embrace the art fray. “It’s a good opportunity to be bold,” says one dealer.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Martina Tuaty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inside the Miami Beach Convention Center, home of the annual Art Basel Miami Beach fair, December 2024.

item.title: ‘The Artist’ Blends Degas and Dollars, Murder and Mandy Patinkin
item.description: Created by Aram Rappaport for his streaming service, the Network, the historical drama explores the tensions, sometimes deadly, between art and commerce.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber and Brian Karlsson
item.media:credit: Brian Karlsson for The New York Times

item.title: Miami Beach’s New Art Installation Frolics With the Fishes
item.description: Our critic explores “Reefline,” an underwater public sculpture park that hopes to be a haven for art and corals. But some question the scientific benefits.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: It’s a Homophobic Slur. What’s It Doing in So Much Theater?
item.description: “Prince Faggot,” “Figaro/Faggots” and other productions use the word to shock, provoke, reclaim it for gay men or all of the above. Does that make it OK?
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.category: The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions (Opera)
The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions (Book)
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: 28 Fun Things to Do in NYC in December 2025
item.description: As the season of Nutcrackers, Messiahs, Scrooges and Santas begins, here are some novel ways to enjoy the holidays, including a poetry weekend and a Coltrane tribute.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.category: Perelman, Ronald O, Performing Arts Center
It's a Wonderful Life: A Live Radio Play (Play)

item.title: Norton Art Museum Hosts Old Masters From the Leiden Collection
item.description: A show of 76 paintings from the Leiden Collection is on display at the Norton Museum of Art in South Florida.
item.dc:creator: Joseph B. Treaster
item.category: Norton Museum of Art (West Palm Beach, Fla)

item.title: Untitled Art Fair in Miami Spotlights Hard-to-Define Artists
item.description: The new Artist Spotlight section of the Miami event will include 30 galleries focusing on a single artist, some chosen in part for their lack of commercialism.
item.dc:creator: Ray Mark Rinaldi

item.title: Why Is Budapest, the ‘City of Baths,’ Running Out of Bathhouses?
item.description: In Budapest, political disputes and aging infrastructure have led to cascading problems, and prolonged closings, at several of the city’s beloved baths.
item.dc:creator: Tas Tóbiás
item.media:credit: Stephen Hiltner/The New York Times
item.media:description: Two of the Art Nouveau pools at Gellért Bath.

item.title: The ‘Race Against Time’ to Save Music Legends’ Decaying Tapes
item.description: New problems are plaguing old reels, putting decades of history at risk. One man, armed with hair dryers and a love of tinkering, is leading the charge to rescue them.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario and Peter Fisher
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry,’ Plus 8 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: A new show based on a Canadian sports romance novel airs. And a reunion of ‘The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives’ recaps the third season.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Crave.
item.media:description: Connor Storrie, left, and Hudson Williams in “Heated Rivarly.”

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’ Season 1, Episode 6 Recap: Daddy’s Little Girl
item.description: Ingrid’s connection to the evil entity known as It is revealed, among other dangerous secrets.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: HBO
item.media:description: It turns out Ingrid (Madeline Stowe) has a clownish side.

item.title: Daniel Woodrell, ‘Country Noir’ Novelist of ‘Winter’s Bone,’ Dies at 72
item.description: His tales of violence and squalor in his native Ozarks had the timeless quality of fables and inspired several movies.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Ulf Andersen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Daniel Woodrell in 2007. “He writes high Greek tragedy about low people, and he never panders or looks down on the people he writes about,” the writer Dennis Lehane said.

item.title: Tom Stoppard Wrote Dialogue for Indiana Jones and Obi-Wan Kenobi
item.description: The playwright won an Academy Award for “Shakespeare in Love.” But he was also a prolific script doctor who worked with filmmakers like Steven Spielberg.
item.dc:creator: Eric Grode
item.category: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (Movie)
item.media:credit: Murray Close/Lucasfilm, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Sean Connery, left, and Harrison Ford during the motorcycle chase scene from the film “Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.”

item.title: The Oxford 2025 Word of the Year Is ‘Rage Bait’
item.description: And if you’re angry about it, that just proves the point.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

item.title: Biyouna, Algerian Star With Tart Tongue Onscreen and Off, Dies at 73
item.description: For generations of Algerians, the fierce independence of her persona reflected their struggles in a country torn by civil war and repression.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Eric Fougere/VIP Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Biyouna in 2015. She was a hero in the working-class Algiers neighborhoods from which she had sprung.

item.title: Stream Movies Written by Tom Stoppard: ‘Shakespeare In Love’ and More
item.description: Spinning off Shakespeare, waltzing through Imperial Russia, bantering about literature or diving deeply into history, Stoppard shared his gifts on the screen.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
